Company: ABB Vetco Gray Inc. and ABB Vetco Gray UK Ltd.
Description: ABB Vetco Gray Inc. and ABB Vetco Gray UK Ltd., U.S. and UK subsidiaries of Swiss company ABB Ltd., pleaded guilty to a criminal information charging each of the two companies with two counts of bribery in violation of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. ABB later sold the business, which eventually ended up as part of General Electric.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/archive/opa/pr/2004/July/04_crm_465.htm

Company: GE Capital Retail Bank and CareCredit
Description: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ordered GE Capital Retail Bank and its subsidiary, CareCredit, to refund up to $34.1 million to potentially more than 1 million consumers who were victims of deceptive credit card enrollment tactics.
Info Source: http://www.consumerfinance.gov/about-us/newsroom/cfpb-orders-ge-carecredit-to-refund-34-1-million-for-deceptive-health-care-credit-card-enrollment/
https://www.faa.gov/about/office_org/headquarters_offices/agc/practice_areas/enforcement/reports/

Company: GE Funding Capital Market Services Inc.
Description: GE Funding Capital Market Services Inc. entered into an agreement with the Department of Justice to resolve the company's role in anticompetitive activity in the municipal bond investments market and agreed to pay a total of $70 million in restitution, penalties and disgorgement to federal and state agencies.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/ge-funding-capital-market-services-inc-admits-anticompetitive-conduct-former-traders

Description: GE Healthcare Inc. paid the United States $30 million, plus interest, to settle allegations that a company it acquired in 2004, Amersham Health Inc., had violated the False Claims Act by causing Medicare to overpay for Myoview, a radiopharmaceutical used in certain cardiac diagnostic imaging procedures.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/ge-healthcare-inc-pays-us-30-million-resolve-false-claims-act-allegations

Description: EPA and General Electric Company entered into a settlement agreement under which the company will conduct a comprehensive study of the contamination in the shoreline areas of the upper Hudson River. The estimated value of this investigation work is $20.5 million. GE will also reimburse EPA for $3.5 million in floodplain-related past costs for a total of $24 million.
Info Source: http://www2.epa.gov/enforcement/case-summary-ge-agrees-further-investigate-upper-hudson-river-floodplain-comprehensive
https://www.sec.gov/news/press/2010/2010-133.htm

Description: General Electric Co. and two of its subcontractors paid the United States $11.5 million to settle a lawsuit that alleges that GE sold defective blades for engines in U.S. military airplanes and helicopters.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/archive/opa/pr/2006/July/06_civ_457.html

Description: General Electric agreed to pay a $2.25 million civil penalty to resolve a complaint alleging violations of federal and state environmental laws in connection with GE's use of an incinerator at a manufacturing facility that it once owned and operated in Waterford, New York.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/general-electric-pay-225-million-violating-federal-and-state-environmental-laws-waterford-new

Description: General Electric agreed to pay a civil penalty of $1.5 billion under the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery, and Enforcement Act of 1989 (FIRREA) to resolve claims involving subprime residential mortgage loans originated by WMC Mortgage, a GE subsidiary. WMC, GE, and their affiliates allegedly misrepresented the quality of WMC's loans and the extent of WMC's internal quality and fraud controls in connection with the marketing and sale of residential mortgage-backed securities.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/general-electric-agrees-pay-15-billion-penalty-alleged-misrepresentations-concerning-subprime

Agency: Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs
Info Source: https://www.dol.gov/ofccp/foia/files/GEAviationCA-Redacted.pdf
https://web.archive.org/web/20141102114633/http://www.doj.state.wi.us/media-center/2009-news-releases/september-29-2009

Description: Home Depot and the new owner of its banking partner GE Capital Corp. agreed to pay the state and customers a total of $672,000 in settlement of allegations it paid off interest free credit card debt from special offers before paying off normal debt, unfairly increasing customers' interest costs. The announcement did not indicate how much each company would pay. Here we assume they split the total equally.
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20091021051746/http://www.ct.gov/ag/cwp/view.asp?A=2426&Q=313314

Description: The West Virginia Attorney General announced that GE Funding Capital Market Services, Trinity Plus Funding Co. LLC, and Trinity Funding Co. LLC would pay a total of $950,000 to settle allegations of illegally rigging bids, fixing prices and manipulating the market for municipal derivatives. The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume the amount was divided equally among the three.
Info Source: West Virginia Attorney General Patrick Morrisey Announces $950,000 Settlement With 3 Financial Institutions, Targeted News Service, July 28, 2014 (via Nexis).

Company: GE Funding Capital Market Services, Inc.
Description: GE Funding Capital Market Services, Inc. paid $34.25 million to settle multistate allegations of anticompetitive and fraudulent conduct in the municipal bond derivatives industry, including bid-rigging and submission of fraudulent certifications of compliance with U.S. Treasury regulations. This was part of a larger $70 million settlement that also involved federal agencies: https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-ge-funding-capital-market-services-inc
Info Source: https://ago.alabama.gov/documents/news/144.pdf
https://web.archive.org/web/20030830155002/http://www.ago.state.ma.us/press_rel/geca.asp

Description: General Electric agreed to pay about $8 million to the New York towns of Stillwater and Waterford to resolve claims for assistance in paying for the use of alternative water supplies made necessary by GE's federally mandated dredging of the Hudson River to remove PCB contamination.
Private Litigation Case Title: Town of Halfmoon et al v. General Electric Company
Info Source: http://s3.amazonaws.com/fcmd/documents/documents/000/003/580/original/General_Electric_-_Stillwater_SETTLEMENT.pdf?1430329175

Description: CSX agreed to a $3 million settlement of a class action brought by residents of Bullitt County, Kentucky living near the site of a derailment that released thick black smoke caused by the burning of hazardous chemicals the train was carrying. General Electric Capital Services was added as a defendant following allegations that the accident was caused by a defect in a rail car owned by that company. It joined in the settlement, which did not specify how much each defendant would pay. Here we assume they split the total cost equally.
Private Litigation Case Title: Green et al v. CSX Corporation et al
Info Source: https://www.lawyersandsettlements.com/settlements/12691/3-million-settlement-in-bullitt-train-class-action.html
